data.text: Characterized by a narrow, often ostentatious concern for academic knowledge and formal rules.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of a pedant or pedantry; overrating the importance of mere learning; also, making an undue or inappropriate display of learning; of language, style, etc., exhibiting pedantry; absurdly learned: as, a pedantic air.
Of or pertaining to a pedant; characteristic of, or resembling, a pedant; ostentatious of learning
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
examples: a <ex>pedantic</ex> writer; a <ex>pedantic</ex> description; a <ex>pedantical</ex> affectation.

data.text: Like a <xref>pedant</xref>, overly concerned with <xref>formal</xref> rules and <xref>trivial</xref> points of learning.

data.text: Being <xref>showy</xref> of one’s <xref>knowledge</xref>, often in a <xref>boring</xref> manner.
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.
from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning especially its trivial aspects
